definition: **noun / technical.** The inherent background level of noise — hiss, hum, surface-whoosh — present in a system or on the vinyl itself below which musical signal sits. Every component in the playback chain contributes: the vinyl compound itself generates surface noise from microscopic imperfections, phono preamps introduce electronic hiss, and turntable motors can add low-frequency rumble. Measured in decibels below peak signal, a lower noise floor reveals more musical detail and increases perceived dynamic range. Virgin vinyl pressings typically achieve -60 to -70 dB, while recycled vinyl may only reach -50 dB due to contaminants. Audiophile pressings on 180-gram virgin vinyl, combined with quality mastering and pristine stampers, can push the noise floor lower, making quiet passages genuinely silent. The format's inherent noise floor — around -70 dB at best — remains vinyl's primary technical limitation compared to digital's -90+ dB. Collectors prize Japanese pressings and early stampers partly for their superior noise floor performance. Modern cleaning methods, anti-static treatments, and high-end cartridges help minimize noise floor intrusion, though some listeners embrace vinyl's characteristic noise signature as part of the format's warmth and authenticity.
etymology: Borrowed from audio engineering terminology in the 1960s, combining 'noise' (unwanted signal) with 'floor' (lowest measurable level), as high-fidelity systems made background noise increasingly audible and measurable.
